citations.narrative:
According to the facility representative, four mandarin ducks and six guineafowl were killed by raccoons in January and
February of 2024. The birds were being housed in the facility’s free-flight aviary which is constructed of rigid metal wire
paneling with approximately 2” x 1” rectangular gaps. The facility representative stated that a small hole was found dug
under the fencing of the enclosure. After the first predation event, the facility began trapping for raccoons in the area.
Failure to provide a safe primary enclosure can result in injury and/or death of the birds contained within. Housing facilities
for birds must be designed and constructed so that they are structurally sound for the species of bird housed in them.
Housing facilities for birds must be kept in good repair, protect the birds from injury, and restrict other animals from
entering that may negatively affect the welfare of the birds within.
To be corrected from this day (7/17/24) forward.

At the time of inspection, the facility did not have updated records of disposition that included the death of four mandarin
ducks and six guineafowl.
Appropriate documentation of regulated animals is essential for proper identification, tracking of animals and for APHIS
Officials to be able to carry out their duties. Exhibitors shall make and maintain complete records regarding the details of
the acquisition and disposition of animals in their possession in order to account for all animal transfers or deaths and the
sources of the animals.
To be corrected by July 24, 2024.

There are numerous nail heads sticking out of the wooden structure surrounding one of the water features in the free-
flight aviary. There are also exposed nail heads sticking out of the shelter for the two swamphens.
Surfaces that have jagged edges or sharp points with which birds can come into contact may cause them injury. Interior
surfaces and surfaces of housing facilities that come in contact with birds must be free of jagged edges or sharp points
that could injure the birds.
To be corrected by July 24, 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
3.150(a)  Critical
   
Facilities, general. 
According to the facility representative, four mandarin ducks and six guineafowl were killed by raccoons in January and 
February of 2024. The birds were being housed in the facility’s free-flight aviary which is constructed of rigid metal wire 
paneling with approximately 2” x 1” rectangular gaps. The facility representative stated that a small hole was found dug 
under the fencing of the enclosure. After the first predation event, the facility began trapping for raccoons in the area.  
Failure to provide a safe primary enclosure can result in injury and/or death of the birds contained within. Housing facilities 
for birds must be designed and constructed so that they are structurally sound for the species of bird housed in them. 
Housing facilities for birds must be kept in good repair, protect the birds from injury, and restrict other animals from 
entering that may negatively affect the welfare of the birds within.  
To be corrected from this day (7/17/24) forward. 
2.75(b)(1) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
At the time of inspection, the facility did not have updated records of disposition that included the death of four mandarin 
ducks and six guineafowl.  
Appropriate documentation of regulated animals is essential for proper identification, tracking of animals and for APHIS 
Officials to be able to carry out their duties. Exhibitors shall make and maintain complete records regarding the details of 
the acquisition and disposition of animals in their possession in order to account for all animal transfers or deaths and the 
sources of the animals. 
To be corrected by July 24, 2024. 
3.150(c)(3) 
   
Facilities, general. 
There are numerous nail heads sticking out of the wooden structure surrounding one of the water features in the free-
flight aviary. There are also exposed nail heads sticking out of the shelter for the two swamphens. 
Surfaces that have jagged edges or sharp points with which birds can come into contact may cause them injury. Interior 
surfaces and surfaces of housing facilities that come in contact with birds must be free of jagged edges or sharp points

that could injure the birds. 
To be corrected by July 24, 2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
